title: The American Revolution
introduction: In the heat of colonial rebellion, you find yourself at the epicenter of an emerging revolution. Whether fighting on the side of the crown or leading the insurgent forces, your choices will define the course of liberty, oppression, and national destiny.

summary.userTemplate: You chose: {decisionSummary}. Your revolution took this path.
summary.historicalOutcome: Historically, the colonies declared independence in 1776, allied with France, and won at Yorktown in 1781.

decisionPoints.question: Amid rising tensions, do you uphold imperial order or embrace the spirit of revolution?

options.feedback: Your firm hand shocks the colonies into submission, yet it stokes the flames of dissent.
Your conciliatory measures ease tensions, though some radicals find them too tepid.
Your discreet support spurs hope among insurgents but risks exposure and backlash from loyalists.

decisionPoints.question: Revolution comes at a cost. How do you secure the resources needed for your campaign?

options.text: Impose Heavier Taxes on the Colonies
options.feedback: The taxes bolster your treasury, yet the colonistsâ€™ ire grows, fueling further resistance.

options.text: Solicit Aid from External Allies (e.g., France)
options.feedback: Support from foreign allies shored up your resources and morale, albeit with strings attached.

options.text: Utilize Revolutionary Fundraising Among the People
options.feedback: Grassroots funding cements popular support, though the funds are modest.

decisionPoints.question: With momentum building, what final strategy will you employ to determine the future of the nation?

options.text: Storm Key Strongholds in a Decisive Battle
options.feedback: Your audacious attack may deliver a swift victory but risks heavy losses and further instability.
A negotiated settlement brings a cautious calm, though some revolutionaries decry it as a half-victory.
Harassing tactics drain your enemy slowly while building a resilient, if unconventional, fighting force.
